business_hypothesis: Increasing top-funnel spend increases impressions per user.
science_hypothesis: A strong positive linear relationship exists (Pearson r ≥ 0.75) between top_funnel_spend_usd and impressions_per_user, with a positive and stable elasticity after controlling for date and brand_search_volume.
null_case: No causal/associative effect: Pearson r ∈ [-0.10, 0.10], regression slope ≈ 0 with p > 0.05, and elasticity indistinguishable from zero.

validation_methods.execution_plan: Estimate OLS regression impressions_per_user ~ top_funnel_spend_usd + log(top_funnel_spend_usd) + date fixed effects + brand_search_volume and compute elasticity = slope * mean(spend)/mean(impressions_per_user). Pass if the linear slope is positive with p < 0.001 and estimated elasticity ≥ 0.30 with the inclusion of spend increasing adjusted R² by ≥ 0.20.

Apply exponential weighting (half-life = 14 days) to spend and impressions and fit weighted OLS and rolling 14-day slopes to capture short-term responsiveness and stability. Pass if the weighted slope remains positive with p < 0.01 and ≥ 75% of rolling 14-day windows show a positive slope.

Run Granger causality tests with lags 1–7 days on daily aggregated top_funnel_spend_usd and impressions_per_user while controlling for autocorrelation and include robustness checks on transformed variables. Pass if top_funnel_spend_usd Granger-causes impressions_per_user with p < 0.01 for at least two contiguous lag orders and the effect is present in ≥ 80% of subsampled periods.
